Research Methodology:

1. Study Design: A randomized controlled trial will be conducted across six European countries to assess the cost-effectiveness of IPS for people with severe mental health problems compared to standard vocational rehabilitation. This study design will allow for a comparison between the two interventions and their impact on employment outcomes.

2. Participant Recruitment: Individuals with severe mental health problems who are unemployed but would like to work will be recruited from mental health services in the six European cities. Participants will be screened for eligibility and randomized into either the IPS group or the standard vocational services group.

3. Intervention: The IPS group will receive individualized support in finding and maintaining paid employment in regular work environments, while the standard vocational services group will receive traditional vocational rehabilitation services. Both groups will be followed for 18 months to assess their employment outcomes.

4. Data Collection: Data on employment outcomes, such as the number of days worked in competitive settings and the percentage of individuals who worked at least 1 day, will be collected at regular intervals throughout the 18-month follow-up period. In addition, cost data related to the delivery of the two intervention programs will be collected.

5. Cost-Effectiveness Analysis: A cost-effectiveness analysis will be conducted to compare the economic case for IPS versus standard vocational services. The analysis will assess the additional cost per additional day worked in competitive settings and the additional cost per additional individual who worked at least 1 day in the IPS group compared to the standard vocational services group.

6. Statistical Analysis: Statistical analysis will be conducted to compare the employment outcomes and costs between the two intervention groups. Regression analysis and other appropriate statistical techniques will be used to account for potential confounding variables and to assess the robustness of the findings.

By implementing this research methodology, we aim to bridge the gap between the existing background knowledge on the cost-effectiveness of supported employment for individuals with autism and those with severe mental health problems and the stated objective of assessing the economic case for IPS compared to standard vocational rehabilitation. This methodology will provide robust evidence on the cost-effectiveness of IPS for individuals with severe mental health problems and contribute to the development of effective supported employment programs for this population.

Research Methodology:

1. Study Design: A randomized controlled trial will be conducted to compare the cost-effectiveness of supported employment and standard care for adults with autism in the United Kingdom. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the supported employment group or the standard care group.

2. Participants: The study will include adults with autism who are seeking employment opportunities. Participants will be recruited from autism support centers, job training programs, and other relevant community organizations. Informed consent will be obtained from all participants before they are enrolled in the study.

3. Data Collection: Data on the number of weeks in employment and QALY will be collected through participant self-report, employment records, and standardized assessments. Participants will be followed up at regular intervals to track their employment status and quality of life.

4. Economic Evaluation: A cost-effectiveness analysis will be conducted to compare the costs and outcomes associated with supported employment and standard care. The costs of implementing supported employment and providing day services will be calculated, including staff salaries, training costs, and program expenses. The outcomes will be measured in terms of the number of weeks in employment and QALY gained.

5. Statistical Analysis: Statistical analysis will be used to compare the differences in employment outcomes and QALY between the two groups. Cost-effectiveness ratios will be calculated to determine the incremental cost-effectiveness of supported employment compared to standard care.

6. Ethical Considerations: The study will adhere to ethical guidelines for research involving human participants, including confidentiality, informed consent, and protection of participant rights.

By implementing this research methodology, the study will effectively bridge the gap between the background knowledge on the effectiveness of supported employment and the objective of assessing its cost-effectiveness. The randomized controlled trial design will provide strong evidence for comparing the outcomes of supported employment and standard care, and the economic evaluation will offer insights into the potential cost savings and benefits of supported employment for adults with autism.
